title: 888: Teams of Agents: The Next Frontier in AI Collaboration â€” with Mike Pell

rawLines.text: This is episode number
888 with Mike Pel, director of the
Microsoft
Garage. Welcome back to the Super Data
Science podcast. I am your host, John
Cone. Today's episode features the
highlights of a session I hosted a
couple weeks ago in Brooklyn at the
inaugural AI and Creativity Summit,
which was run by Artist and the Machine.
It was an excellent full day event on a
gloriously sunny day. My guest for an
onstage conversation in front of a live
audience was the extraordinary Mike Pel.
Mike is the inventor of the PDF, an
Adobe Acrobat. He is director of the
Microsoft Garage, a global innovation
program. He holds over 20 US patents and
is the author of three books. Today's
episode is entertaining, optimistic, and
forward-looking and will be of interest
to any listener to this podcast. In it,
Mike details why AI agents are an
exoskeleton that gives you capabilities
you never had time to master. He talks
about the coming shift from passive to
proactive AI that will interject like a
trusted co-orker. And he talks about why
he believes we're getting to the good
part in the AI revolution and what that
means for the future of work. Note that
near the end of the episode, Mike and I
take audience questions, but the
audience members didn't have a
microphone, so we'll skip the dead air
of them asking questions and jump right
to Mike or me repeating back the
question for you guys. All right, now
let's jump right into our conversation.
Here we go. I've been at Microsoft for
23 years. The garage, the last 10 of
those. Gotcha. Don't Don't tell anybody
I've been there that long. It's it's
just embarrassing. And so the garage is
described as a program that drives
Microsoft's innovation culture. How do
you cultivate that mindset among
employees on a day-to-day basis? For
example, are there particular
practices that uh our audience could
hear about that allows them to have a
more innovative workplace themselves?
It's funny you say that, John, because I
think most people want to do innovative
things. your job or your role may not
call for that, but we find that people
really to the person want to do
something more than maybe what they're
doing. And so naturally, we're all drawn
to the ability to jump in and do
something new and exciting. At
Microsoft, we figured out about 10 years
ago when Satin Nadella became the new
CEO that we could create a mechanism and
sort of an um a way for people to do
this as part of their day job without it
seeing special, right? So we that was
our thing. We could never do whatever
20% time or you get a day a week to do
whatever you want because we're all too
busy. What we figured out was if we
tried to change the culture to be more
curious and more experimental that would
bake it into everything we did. It would
be in the water and so it wouldn't be a
like a strange alien thing to do. It
would just be what we all did. And
that's what I think all of you could
sort of practice yourselves. But like
practically how do you do that? Like
it's it just seems it seems like an easy
thing to say like yeah we'll have a
curiosity culture but how how do you do
you just you have put signs up that say
be curious. No, actually you you don't
put signs up. You tell people not to ask
permission, which sounds terrible,
right? Attorneys don't like that. If you
ask somebody, can I innovate? Can I do
something new? Of course, the answer is
going to be no. But you literally have
to tell people, just do it. Just do it.
Prove that it either works or it doesn't
work. Bring me some data back that shows
me that that proves your point so that
we can continue doing this. But it's
it's not something where you can just
say, "Hey, everybody, let's all be
creative." because that that's never
going to work right but to the person if
you make a connection you say I know
that you're very talented with this I
know you have a great idea over here
people will go off and do it all right
so let's talk about some now some
specific innovations that are making a
lot of
buzz enterprise agentic AI so this year
2025 seems to be the year of agentic AI
uh you had an interesting perspective to
me that you relayed me last week around
how AI agents are like an exoskeleton
available to us at all times so that we
can do things we could never have done
before. Do you want to elaborate on that
more? Sure. I I think in general uh AI
is a superpower for people. Meaning it's
going to allow you to do things that
maybe you would never have time to do,
you didn't know how to do, or or you
really even given the time could never
really master. So to me this is sort of
an exoskeleton like an Iron Man suit
that you put on that gives you these
capabilities without you having to dig
very deep which is the magic of it. Now
the agent part is when you take some of
those capabilities and package it up
into something that feels like a trusted
co-orker or an adviser or someone who's
very specialized. So, you know, for us,
artificial intelligence, all of you, I'm
sure, have tried this out and did, you
know, very interesting things, is the
underlying um technology, but the agent
is the packaging that sort of feels like
a person in a
way. Uh, quick audience question. How
much has It seems like maybe the
mezzanine noise just dropped down, but
was that making it was all the noise up
there making it difficult to hear us or
it was Okay. Okay. Nice. I can see you
have speakers all around you.
Uh, it seems to quiet it down now a bit
anyway, so I don't have to reprimand
them. I think we're boring them. They
all left the mezzanine people. No, now
they're so engaged listening to this.
They they open the bar upstairs.
Um, all right. Yeah. So, great
perspective there on AI agents being an
exoskeleton. Um, let's now talk about
human AI collaboration more
specifically in the business place. So
AI is increasingly becoming a co-worker
in our daily jobs rather than just a
tool.
Microsoft has AI efforts that are
branded like that. They're like co-pilot

between humans and AI. So for example,
the new Microsoft 365 co-pilot uh can

discussions, highlight action items as
an active assistant, which sounds a lot

really a question, but I do have a
question that now follows on from that.
Wait, I was going to have a response.
Okay, go go. Okay, so that the
interesting part of what you just said
to me is that yes, like AI is a lot of
different things. the part that people
don't realize about uh these models,
right, and these agents and these
things, they're incredibly capable of so
many things you don't realize. And it's
not until you start asking it certain

It literally can act like an adviser or

know that they can go that deep. you
know, when so the the acronym GPT, the P
is pre-trained, meaning it's got an
incredible amount of knowledge. I know
that you dig into this, uh, but a lot of
people just don't realize that there is
so much to the model that you haven't
even, you know, heard about. We haven't

it feels like that expert that you
talked to.
Nice. I'm so glad that was I made up my

a response. It's perfect. uh but I did I
kind of have a followup question from

which is that so with many people

envision AI is a

when humans and AI work side by side on

shift from where we are now, which is uh
a bit of a passive model, right? The AI

that will flip and they'll start to

"Hey, Mike, did you really mean this

actually being an active participant,

co-orker who you can trust. And the
trust part is the most important part.
Nice. Yeah, I think as error rates go
down, you can trust more and more. So
when I'm using deep research from OpenAI
for example, it is
unbelievable, you know, and when you so
when you have that level of accuracy,
that level of trust, the more tasks you

and and as always, the trust is earned,
right? It's it's got to do the right

start to trust it. Which is by the way
the downfall of humanity is that we
start to trust technology and we stop

stop paying attention that's when
problems come out. So I would just ask
all of you as you're using all these new
technologies do not fall asleep at the
wheel. Don't trust it so much that you
don't verify.
Classic KGB
situation. Trust but verify.
Um, so yeah, right now in terms of
specific examples that we have AI

things the kinds of things that we trust
them with, uh, are helping with code. So
like GitHub Copilot, writing and
summarizing text. Well, you know, I I'll
just tell you really quickly, GitHub
Copilot almost didn't happen because the
very first versions, they weren't

know programmers, engineers are very

went, "Oh, this is never going to work.
Look, like stupid syntax error." That
was the very beginning. If they had

sort of lost sight of the bigger

yeah so where I was going with that is
that so things like GitHub copilot for
writing code we have LLMs for writing
and summarizing text even generating
images video from your view at the
Microsoft garage what are the most
exciting or impactful instances of human
AI
collaboration to come
so this happens quite a bit for us in

to work with the world's most successful
uccessful companies and disrupt their

AI can actually accelerate parts of what

it's just unexpected because it's so

And so that's the biggest disruption.
That's the biggest change we see is that

I mean so that gives us kind of a sense

but is there something that you think
maybe we can't do today that we will be

what's around the corner? Uh the thing

Like right now, yes, through

this problem of if you have a even just
a 1% error rate um on decisions that are

you know some kind of issue arising
through that multi- aent system. So I
think or or it goes the other way like
we just don't know yet, right? It it

Yeah, you could set it up deliberately
to have an agent that's reviewing. Yeah.
Well, and that's that's the

we're trying to build into these

pay me so much.
Um, so,
uh, for professionals who aren't AI
experts but are starting to have AI
tools in their workflow, what's your
advice to collaborate effectively with
AI? Like, how can people take the best
advantage of AI assistants or AI agents
that are available today? Uh,
particularly maybe if you're not, you
know, a coder yourself. Mhm. The first
thing that I do is tell people you do
not have to take a class. Okay? Every
people ask me all the time, what class
should I take to learn about AI? And I
tell them, don't take any class. Just
talk to it like it's a person. Pick your
favorite one. Whether it's co-pilot or
chat GBT or CLA, it doesn't matter. Talk
to it like a person. Ask it something
you would ask one of your friends or a
family or a co-orker. Start a
conversation. That's how you're going to
learn to use it effectively because then
you'll start to figure out what types of
questions are most effective to get work
done like work whatever that work
happens to be. The next advice I give
them is don't try to use it for a big
project. use it for something small like
you know get little wins build on on
being able to do something quickly and
eventually you'll get enough you know
expertise or enough you know I would say
trust and um confidence to then start to
talk to your teammates about what they
do and that's when the you know the
multiplier effect comes in when you
actually can work with someone else not
just you and the AI but you you know
your assistant and other assistants
together that's when you start to
realize the power of using this in a
team setting. Nice. Very cool. Um, all
right. So, shifting gears here a little
bit. We've been talking in my last few
questions about human AI collaboration.
I would now love to pick your brain, not
just about the future of AI and how we
can be working with it, but how work
will be transformed by AI, human work.
So you highlighted for me in a
conversation that we had last week the
importance of soft skills like
creativity relative to automatable hard
skills and you had the specific example
of how Italian students I don't know if
this is all Italian students but I guess
Italian students frequently have oral
exams and you said that many American
students would fail that but AI could be
part of the solution. Do you want to
elaborate on this? Yeah, absolutely. Um,
what we're seeing, I I'll just
generalize in corporate America, we're
seeing students come out of school
without some of the most basic of skills
that you would expect. The ability to
communicate clearly, to debate, to
critically think about things, to be
able to um operate, you know, in the
moment. These are really smart kids,
right? They are so much smarter than the
previous generation. But these skills
that used to be called the humanities
are sort of missing from from you know
what they're bringing to their jobs. So
what we're seeing is that we need the
ability for students for people early in
their careers to master these soft
skills like being able to to talk and
and communicate and and have
conversations because the hard skill
part of their role is going to be
automated by the machine, right? the
engineering, the medicine, the biology,
all the hard skill stuff will be
available through the system. What's
missing is their business savvy and
their ability to actually, you know, be
a really valuable person. So, the the
future of work that I'm seeing is not
relying on um using AI to get better at
the hard skill because that's going to
be sort of a given. use AI to become
better at at being able to be a great
teammate, to be a great coach, to be a
great collaborator. That's sort of the,
you know, that's the future of
everybody's job. It's not just a few
people. Every single one of us are going
to have to get great at that because
trust me, parts of what you do will be
automated in some way, you know, but
that's not the important part. The
important part is that you're still a
person. You're super smart, right? You
are more clever than the machine is ever
going to be. That's what we want out of
